Situation1: They notice a minor ethical dilemma at work, like someone cutting in line, and feel a mild urge to act.
Expectation2: Arrive at the polling station during designated voting hours
Situation2: Polls stay open all day and the voter has a light schedule.
Story:
I stood in the long queue at the polling station, my voter slip clutched in my hand. The line moved slowly, but I had no pressing appointments—just the quiet satisfaction of fulfilling my duty as a citizen. As I waited, I noticed a man quietly slip ahead, bypassing several people. My heart twinged. As a Hindu, I was taught to uphold dharma—righteousness and fairness—even in small matters. I felt a gentle but persistent urge to speak up, to remind him and everyone else that fairness matters, even in something as mundane as a queue.

But then, the other part of me—the voter—whispered that my main responsibility here was to cast my ballot. The line was long, but the polls would be open all day. If I caused a scene, would it delay things for everyone? Would I be seen as disruptive, or worse, as someone trying to make a simple civic act complicated? The expectations of my faith and my civic role pressed in on me from both sides, and I found myself frozen, wrestling with what to do next.
